### Exercise 1

Consider the following context-free grammar $G:S → SS + | SS ∗ | a$

1. Is the string a + a ∗ a in L(G)? [10 points] 

2. Give a leftmost derivation for the string aa ∗ aa + ∗. [10 points] 
   $$
   S \rightarrow SS* \\
   S \rightarrow SS*S* \\
   S \rightarrow aa*S* \\
   S \rightarrow aa*SS+* \\
   S \rightarrow aa*aa+*
   $$


3. Give a rightmost derivation for the string aa ∗ aa + ∗. [10 points] 
   $$
   S \rightarrow SS* \\
   S \rightarrow SSS+* \\
   S \rightarrow Saa+* \\
   S \rightarrow SS*aa+* \\
   S \rightarrow aa*aa+*
   $$
   
4. Give a parse tree for the string aa ∗ aa + ∗. [10 points] 

   ![img](data:image/png;base64,)
   
5. Give an equivalent grammar without immediate left recursions. [10 points]
   $$
   S \rightarrow aS' \\
   S \rightarrow S+S' |S*S' | \epsilon
   $$
   

### Exercise 2 (Top-Down Parsing)

Consider the following grammar 


$$
G: S → aB
$$

$$
B → S + B | ϵ
$$

1. Construct the predictive parsing table for $G$. Please put down the detailed steps, including the calculation of FIRST and FOLLOW sets. [25 points] 
   $$
   \text{FIRST}(S) = \{a\} \\
   \text{FIRST}(B) = \{a, \epsilon\} \\
   \text{FIRST}(a) = \{a\} \\
   \text{FIRST}(+) = \{+\} \\
   \\
   \text{FOLLOW}(S)= \{\$, +\}\\
   \text{FOLLOW}(B) = \{\$, +\}
   $$
|            |  $\text{a}$  |   $\text{+}$   |  $\text{\$}$   |
| :--------: | :----------: | :------------: | :------------: |
| $\text{S}$ | $\text{aB}$  | $\text{ERROR}$ | $\text{ERROR}$ |
| $\text{B}$ | $\text{S+B}$ |  $\text{S+B}$  |  $\text{S+B}$  |

Is the grammar LL(1)? [5 points] 

Yes

2. Can an LL(1) parser accept the input string $\text{aaaa+++}$? If yes, please list the moves made by the parser; otherwise, state the reason. Before parsing, please resolve conflicts in the parsing table if any. [20 points] 

   | $\text{input}$ | $\text{symbol}$  |
   | :------------: | :--------------: |
   |                |    $\text{S}$    |
   |   $\text{a}$   |   $\text{aB}$    |
   |   $\text{a}$   |  $\text{aS+B}$   |
   |   $\text{a}$   |  $\text{aaB+B}$  |
   |   $\text{a}$   | $\text{aaS+B+B}$ |
   |   $\text{+}$   |  $\text{ERROR}$  |

   

### Optional Exercise (20 bonus points) 

Consider the following context-free grammar:
$$
短语 → 人 | 短语 动词 短语
$$

$$
动词 → 喜欢 | 讨厌
$$

$$
人 → 你 | 我 | 他
$$

The grammar can produce sentences such as “我喜欢你”. Is the grammar ambiguous? If yes, please give one sentence and its multiple parse trees. If no, state the reason. [5 points for the yes/no answer and 15 points for the justification]

​	Yes, the grammar is ambiguous. For example, there are two syntax tree for the same sentence "我喜欢他讨厌我"

![img](data:image/png;base64,)



![img](data:image/png;base64,)
